sn17.10:1.3.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ passāmi sakkārena abhibhūtaṃ pariyādiṇṇacittaṃ, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannaṃ.
sn17.10:1.3.eng: Take a case where I see a certain individual whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by honor. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

sn17.10:1.4.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ passāmi asakkārena abhibhūtaṃ pariyādiṇṇacittaṃ, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannaṃ.
sn17.10:1.4.eng: Take another case where I see a certain individual whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by lack of honor. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

sn17.10:1.5.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ passāmi sakkārena ca asakkārena ca tadubhayena abhibhūtaṃ pariyādiṇṇacittaṃ, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannaṃ.
sn17.10:1.5.eng: And take another case where I see a certain individual whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by both honor and lack of honor. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

sn17.10:1.6.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.10:2.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn17.10:2.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn17.10:2.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn17.10:3.4.eng: as they abide in the immeasurables.

sn17.10:4.3.eng: Rejoicing in the ending of grasping,

sn17.10:4.4.eng: they’re said to be a true person.”

sn17.11:1.3.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
sn17.11:1.3.eng: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:

sn17.11:1.4.pli: ‘na cāyamāyasmā suvaṇṇapātiyāpi rūpiyacuṇṇaparipūrāya hetu sampajānamusā bhāseyyā’ti.
sn17.11:1.4.eng: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of a gold cup filled with silver powder.’

sn17.11:1.5.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūtaṃ pariyādiṇṇacittaṃ sampajānamusā bhāsantaṃ.
sn17.11:1.5.eng: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.11:1.6.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.12:1.3.pli: idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
sn17.12:1.3.eng: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:

sn17.12:1.4.pli: ‘na cāyamāyasmā rūpiyapātiyāpi suvaṇṇacuṇṇaparipūrāya hetu sampajānamusā bhāseyyā’ti.
sn17.12:1.4.eng: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of a silver pot filled with gold powder.’

sn17.12:1.5.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūtaṃ pariyādiṇṇacittaṃ sampajānamusā bhāsantaṃ.
sn17.12:1.5.eng: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.12:1.6.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.13-20:1.2.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
sn17.13-20:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:

sn17.13-20:1.3.eng: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of a gold ingot.’ …”

sn17.13-20:1.4.eng: “‘… for the sake of a hundred gold ingots.’ …”

sn17.13-20:1.5.eng: “‘… for the sake of a mountain of gold.’ …”
sn17.13-20:1.5.comm: The Purāṇas list the nikkha (“ingot”) as the largest gold coin, but here a siṅgīnikkha must be much more than a hundred of the largest coins, and hence cannot be a coin at all. Siṅgīsuvaṇṇa means “mountain gold” (AN 3.70:38.3). Given that the next step is the entire earth, perhaps siṅgīnikkha means “golden mountain”. A “golden mountain” (pabbatassa suvaṇṇassa) appears in a similar context at SN 4.20:3.2.

sn17.13-20:1.6.eng: “‘… for the sake of a hundred mountains of gold.’ …”

sn17.13-20:1.7.eng: “‘… for the sake of the whole earth full of gold.’ …”

sn17.13-20:1.8.eng: “‘… for any kind of material reward.’ …”

sn17.13-20:1.10.eng: “‘… for the sake of the finest lady in the land.’

sn17.13-20:1.11.pli: Tamenaṃ passāmi aparena samayena lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūtaṃ pariyādiṇṇacittaṃ sampajānamusā bhāsantaṃ.
sn17.13-20:1.11.eng: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.13-20:1.12.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.2:1.2.pli: “Dāruṇo, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko kaṭuko pharuso antarāyiko anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
sn17.2:1.2.eng: “Possessions, honor, and popularity are grim, bitter, and harsh. They’re an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

sn17.2:1.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, bāḷisiko āmisagataṃ baḷisaṃ gambhīre udakarahade pakkhipeyya.
sn17.2:1.3.eng: Suppose an angler was to cast a baited hook into a deep lake.

sn17.2:1.4.eng: Seeing the bait, a fish would swallow it.

sn17.2:1.5.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, maccho gilabaḷiso bāḷisikassa anayaṃ āpanno byasanaṃ āpanno yathākāmakaraṇīyo bāḷisikassa.
sn17.2:1.5.eng: And so the fish that swallowed the hook would meet with tragedy and disaster, and the angler can do what he wants with it.

sn17.2:2.1.pli: Bāḷisikoti kho, bhikkhave, mārassetaṃ pāpimato adhivacanaṃ.
sn17.2:2.1.eng: ‘Angler’ is a term for Māra the Wicked.

sn17.2:2.2.eng: ‘Hook’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.2:2.3.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ lābhasakkārasilokaṃ assādeti nikāmeti, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gilabaḷiso mārassa anayaṃ āpanno byasanaṃ āpanno yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato.
sn17.2:2.3.eng: Whoever enjoys and likes arisen possessions, honor, and popularity is called a mendicant who has swallowed Māra’s hook. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

sn17.2:2.4.pli: Evaṃ dāruṇo kho, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko kaṭuko pharuso antarāyiko anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
sn17.2:2.4.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity—bitter and harsh, an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

sn17.2:2.5.eng: So you should train like this:

sn17.2:2.6.pli: ‘uppannaṃ lābhasakkārasilokaṃ pajahissāma, na ca no uppanno lābhasakkārasiloko cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatī’ti.
sn17.2:2.6.eng: ‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity, and we won’t let them occupy our minds.’

sn17.21:1.3.pli: na tassa, bhikkhave, mātugāmo eko ekassa cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati yassa lābhasakkārasiloko cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
sn17.21:1.3.eng: Even if you’re alone with a lady she might not occupy your mind, but possessions, honor and popularity would still occupy your mind.

sn17.21:1.4.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.22:0.3.eng: The Finest Lady in the Land

sn17.22:1.3.pli: na tassa, bhikkhave, janapadakalyāṇī ekā ekassa cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati yassa lābhasakkārasiloko cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
sn17.22:1.3.eng: Even if you’re alone with the finest lady in the land she might not occupy your mind, but possessions, honor and popularity would still occupy your mind.

sn17.22:1.4.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.23:1.3.pli: saddhā, bhikkhave, upāsikā ekaputtakaṃ piyaṃ manāpaṃ evaṃ sammā āyācamānā āyāceyya:
sn17.23:1.3.eng: A faithful laywoman with a dear and beloved only son would rightly appeal to him,

sn17.23:1.4.pli: ‘tādiso, tāta, bhavāhi yādiso citto ca gahapati hatthako ca āḷavako’ti.
sn17.23:1.4.eng: ‘My darling, please be like the householder Citta and Hatthaka of Āḷavī.’
sn17.23:1.4.comm: Also at AN 2.132:1.3 and  AN 4.176:3.2. | An entire Saṁyutta is devoted to Citta (SN 41), the foremost layman in teaching Dhamma (AN 1.250). | Hatthaka, the foremost in attracting a congregation (AN 1.251), is featured especially in AN 7.23 and AN 7.24.

sn17.23:1.5.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṃ pamāṇaṃ mama sāvakānaṃ upāsakānaṃ, yadidaṃ citto ca gahapati hatthako ca āḷavako.
sn17.23:1.5.eng: These are a standard and a measure for my male lay disciples, that is, the householder Citta and Hatthaka of Āḷavī.

sn17.23:1.6.pli: Sace kho tvaṃ, tāta, agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajasi;
sn17.23:1.6.eng: ‘But my darling, if you go forth from the lay life to homelessness,

sn17.23:1.7.eng: please be like Sāriputta and Moggallāna.’

sn17.23:1.8.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṃ pamāṇaṃ mama sāvakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ, yadidaṃ sāriputtamoggalānā.
sn17.23:1.8.eng: These are a standard and a measure for my monk disciples, that is, Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

sn17.23:1.9.pli: Mā ca kho tvaṃ, tāta, sekhaṃ appattamānasaṃ lābhasakkārasiloko anupāpuṇātūti.
sn17.23:1.9.eng: ‘And my darling, may you not come into possessions, honor, and popularity while you’re still a trainee and haven’t achieved your heart’s desire.’

sn17.23:1.10.pli: Tañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ sekhaṃ appattamānasaṃ lābhasakkārasiloko anupāpuṇāti, so tassa hoti antarāyāya.
sn17.23:1.10.eng: If a trainee who hasn’t achieved their heart’s desire comes into possessions, honor, and popularity it’s an obstacle for them.

sn17.23:1.11.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.24:1.3.pli: saddhā bhikkhave upāsikā ekaṃ dhītaraṃ piyaṃ manāpaṃ evaṃ sammā āyācamānā āyāceyya:
sn17.24:1.3.eng: A faithful laywoman with a dear and beloved only daughter would rightly appeal to her,

sn17.24:1.4.pli: ‘tādisā, ayye, bhavāhi yādisā khujjuttarā ca upāsikā veḷukaṇḍakiyā ca nandamātā’ti.
sn17.24:1.4.eng: ‘My darling, please be like the laywomen Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇṭakī, Nanda’s mother.’
sn17.24:1.4.comm: Also at AN 2.133 and AN 4.176:4.2. | Khujjuttarā was the most learned of the laywomen (AN 1.260). | Veḷukaṇṭakī features as a meditator, reciter, and donor at AN 6.37 and AN 7.53. She is probably the same person as Uttarā Nanda’s mother who was the foremost laywoman jhana practitioner (AN 1.262).

sn17.24:1.5.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṃ pamāṇaṃ mama sāvikānaṃ upāsikānaṃ, yadidaṃ khujjuttarā ca upāsikā veḷukaṇḍakiyā ca nandamātā.
sn17.24:1.5.eng: These are a standard and a measure for my female lay disciples, that is, the laywomen Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇṭakī, Nanda’s mother.

sn17.24:1.6.pli: Sace kho tvaṃ, ayye, agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajasi;
sn17.24:1.6.eng: ‘But my darling, if you go forth from the lay life to homelessness,

sn17.24:1.7.pli: tādisā, ayye, bhavāhi yādisā khemā ca bhikkhunī uppalavaṇṇā cāti.
sn17.24:1.7.eng: please be like the nuns Khemā and Uppalavaṇṇā.’
sn17.24:1.7.comm: Also at AN 2.131 and AN 4.176:2.2. | Uppalavaṇṇā was the foremost nun in psychic powers (AN 1.237), which kept her fearless when demolishing Māra (SN 5.5). Her verses are at Thig 11.1, and she was as a teacher of nuns (Thig 13.5:27.3, Kd 20:8.1.1). A Vinaya story shows her gratitude to the Buddha (Bu NP 5:1.1.1). She was a survivor of sexual assault (Bu Pj 1:10.5.1). | Khemā was extolled as the foremost nun in wisdom (AN 1.236); her verses are at Thig 6.3; and she teaches King Pasenadi in SN 44.1.

sn17.24:1.8.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṃ pamāṇaṃ mama sāvikānaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ, yadidaṃ khemā ca bhikkhunī uppalavaṇṇā ca.
sn17.24:1.8.eng: These are a standard and a measure for my nun disciples, that is, the nuns Khemā and Uppalavaṇṇā.

sn17.24:1.9.pli: Mā ca kho tvaṃ, ayye, sekhaṃ appattamānasaṃ lābhasakkārasiloko anupāpuṇātūti.
sn17.24:1.9.eng: ‘And my darling, may you not come into possessions, honor, and popularity while you’re still a trainee and haven’t achieved your heart’s desire.’

sn17.24:1.10.pli: Tañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuniṃ sekhaṃ appattamānasaṃ lābhasakkārasiloko anupāpuṇāti, so tassā hoti antarāyāya.
sn17.24:1.10.eng: If a trainee who hasn’t achieved their heart’s desire comes into possessions, honor, and popularity it’s an obstacle for them.

sn17.24:1.11.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.25:1.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā lābhasakkārasilokassa assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti,
sn17.25:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand the gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.25:1.3.pli: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca pana te āyasmantā sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn17.25:1.3.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn17.25:1.4.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā lābhasakkārasilokassa assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti,
sn17.25:1.4.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand the gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.25:1.5.pli: te ca kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn17.25:1.5.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn17.26:1.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā lābhasakkārasilokassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn17.26:1.2.eng: “There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to possessions, honor, and popularity …

sn17.26:1.3.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand …”

sn17.27:1.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā lābhasakkārasilokaṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, lābhasakkārasilokasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, lābhasakkārasilokanirodhaṃ nappajānanti, lābhasakkārasilokanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn17.27:1.2.eng: “There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand possessions, honor, and popularity, their origin, their cessation, and the path that leads to their cessation …

sn17.27:1.3.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand …”

sn17.28:1.3.pli: Lābhasakkārasiloko, bhikkhave, chaviṃ chindati, chaviṃ chetvā cammaṃ chindati, cammaṃ chetvā maṃsaṃ chindati, maṃsaṃ chetvā nhāruṃ chindati, nhāruṃ chetvā aṭṭhiṃ chindati, aṭṭhiṃ chetvā aṭṭhimiñjaṃ āhacca tiṭṭhati.
sn17.28:1.3.eng: They cut through the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, sinews, and bones, until they reach the marrow and keep pressing.

sn17.28:1.4.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.29:1.3.pli: Lābhasakkārasiloko, bhikkhave, chaviṃ chindati, chaviṃ chetvā cammaṃ chindati, cammaṃ chetvā maṃsaṃ chindati, maṃsaṃ chetvā nhāruṃ chindati, nhāruṃ chetvā aṭṭhiṃ chindati, aṭṭhiṃ chetvā aṭṭhimiñjaṃ āhacca tiṭṭhati.
sn17.29:1.3.eng: They cut through the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, sinews, and bones, until they reach the marrow and keep pressing.

sn17.29:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, balavā puriso daḷhāya vāḷarajjuyā jaṅghaṃ veṭhetvā ghaṃseyya.
sn17.29:2.1.eng: Suppose a strong man was to twist a strong horse-hair rope around your shin and tighten it.

sn17.29:2.2.pli: Sā chaviṃ chindeyya, chaviṃ chetvā cammaṃ chindeyya, cammaṃ chetvā maṃsaṃ chindeyya, maṃsaṃ chetvā nhāruṃ chindeyya, nhāruṃ chetvā aṭṭhiṃ chindeyya, aṭṭhiṃ chetvā aṭṭhimiñjaṃ āhacca tiṭṭheyya.
sn17.29:2.2.eng: It would cut through the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, sinews, and bones, until it reached the marrow and kept pressing.

sn17.29:2.3.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko chaviṃ chindati, chaviṃ chetvā cammaṃ chindati, cammaṃ chetvā maṃsaṃ chindati, maṃsaṃ chetvā nhāruṃ chindati, nhāruṃ chetvā aṭṭhiṃ chindati, aṭṭhiṃ chetvā aṭṭhimiñjaṃ āhacca tiṭṭhati.
sn17.29:2.3.eng: In the same way, possessions, honor, and popularity cut through the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, sinews, and bones, until they reach the marrow and keep pressing.

sn17.29:2.4.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.3:1.3.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, aññatarasmiṃ udakarahade mahākummakulaṃ ciranivāsi ahosi.
sn17.3:1.3.eng: Once upon a time in a certain lake there was a large family of turtles that had lived there for a long time.

sn17.3:1.4.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññataro kummo aññataraṃ kummaṃ etadavoca:
sn17.3:1.4.eng: Then one of the turtles said to another,

sn17.3:1.5.pli: ‘mā kho tvaṃ, tāta kumma, etaṃ padesaṃ agamāsī’ti.
sn17.3:1.5.eng: ‘My dear turtle, don’t you go to that place.’

sn17.3:1.6.pli: Agamāsi kho, bhikkhave, so kummo taṃ padesaṃ.
sn17.3:1.6.eng: But that turtle did go to that place,

sn17.3:1.7.eng: and a hunter pierced her with a harpoon.

sn17.3:1.8.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, so kummo yena so kummo tenupasaṅkami.
sn17.3:1.8.eng: Then that turtle went back to the other turtle.

sn17.3:1.9.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, so kummo taṃ kummaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
sn17.3:1.9.eng: When the other turtle saw her coming off in the distance,

sn17.3:1.11.pli: ‘kacci tvaṃ, tāta kumma, na taṃ padesaṃ agamāsī’ti?
sn17.3:1.11.eng: ‘My dear turtle, I hope you didn’t go to that place!’

sn17.3:1.13.eng: ‘But my dear turtle, I hope you’re not hurt or injured!’

sn17.3:1.14.pli: ‘Akkhato khomhi, tāta kumma, anupahato, atthi ca me idaṃ suttakaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhan’ti.
sn17.3:1.14.eng: ‘I’m not hurt or injured. But this cord keeps dragging behind me.’

sn17.3:1.15.eng: ‘Indeed, my dear turtle, you’re hurt and injured!

sn17.3:1.16.pli: Etena hi te, tāta kumma, suttakena pitaro ca pitāmahā ca anayaṃ āpannā byasanaṃ āpannā.
sn17.3:1.16.eng: Your father and grandfather met with tragedy and disaster because of such a cord.

sn17.3:1.17.pli: Gaccha dāni tvaṃ, tāta kumma, na dāni tvaṃ amhākan’ti.
sn17.3:1.17.eng: Go now, you are no longer one of us.’

sn17.3:2.1.pli: Luddoti kho, bhikkhave, mārassetaṃ pāpimato adhivacanaṃ.
sn17.3:2.1.eng: ‘Hunter’ is a term for Māra the Wicked.

sn17.3:2.2.eng: ‘Harpoon’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.3:2.3.eng: ‘Cord’ is a term for greed and relishing.

sn17.3:2.4.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ lābhasakkārasilokaṃ assādeti nikāmeti—
sn17.3:2.4.eng: Whoever enjoys and likes arisen possessions, honor, and popularity is called a mendicant who has been pierced with a harpoon. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

sn17.3:2.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu giddho papatāya anayaṃ āpanno byasanaṃ āpanno yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato.

sn17.3:2.6.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.30:1.2.pli: “Yopi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo tassapāhaṃ lābhasakkārasiloko antarāyāya vadāmī”ti.
sn17.30:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, possessions, honor, and popularity are an obstacle even for a mendicant who is perfected, with defilements ended.”

sn17.30:1.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn17.30:1.3.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

sn17.30:1.4.pli: “kissa pana, bhante, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno lābhasakkārasiloko antarāyāyā”ti?
sn17.30:1.4.eng: “Sir, what do possessions, honor, and popularity obstruct for a mendicant with defilements ended?”

sn17.30:1.5.pli: “Yā hissa sā, ānanda, akuppā cetovimutti nāhaṃ tassā lābhasakkārasilokaṃ antarāyāya vadāmi.
sn17.30:1.5.eng: “Ānanda, I don’t say that possessions, honor, and popularity obstruct the unshakable freedom of heart.

sn17.30:1.6.pli: Ye ca khvassa, ānanda, appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārā adhigatā tesāhamassa lābhasakkārasilokaṃ antarāyāya vadāmi.
sn17.30:1.6.eng: But I do say that possessions, honor, and popularity obstruct the achievement of blissful meditations in this life for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
sn17.30:1.6.comm: Even for an arahant, the burden of popularity and wealth takes them away from their meditation.

sn17.30:1.7.pli: Evaṃ dāruṇo kho, ānanda, lābhasakkārasiloko kaṭuko pharuso antarāyiko anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
sn17.30:1.7.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity—bitter and harsh, an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

sn17.30:1.8.eng: So you should train like this:

sn17.30:1.9.pli: ‘uppannaṃ lābhasakkārasilokaṃ pajahissāma, na ca no uppanno lābhasakkārasiloko cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatī’ti.
sn17.30:1.9.eng: ‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity, and we won’t let them occupy our minds.’

sn17.31:1.3.pli: Lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūto pariyādiṇṇacitto, bhikkhave, devadatto saṅghaṃ bhindi.
sn17.31:1.3.eng: Devadatta split the Saṅgha because his mind was overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.31:1.4.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.32:1.3.pli: Lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūtassa pariyādiṇṇacittassa, bhikkhave, devadattassa kusalamūlaṃ samucchedamagamā.
sn17.32:1.3.eng: Devadatta cut off his skillful root because his mind was overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
sn17.32:1.3.comm: Contentment, love, and understanding. Note, “skillful root” may be expressed in the singular even though it is threefold (MN 9:7.1).

sn17.32:1.4.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.33:1.3.pli: Lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūtassa pariyādiṇṇacittassa, bhikkhave, devadattassa kusalo dhammo samucchedamagamā.
sn17.33:1.3.eng: Devadatta cut off his skillful quality because his mind was overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.33:1.4.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

sn17.34:1.3.pli: Lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūtassa pariyādiṇṇacittassa, bhikkhave, devadattassa sukko dhammo samucchedamagamā.
sn17.34:1.3.eng: Devadatta cut off his bright quality because his mind was overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.34:1.4.eng: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”
